This modified silica was used as a catalyst in the substitution reaction of halides by cyanide ion, the alkylation of malononitrile and phenylacetonitrile (PAN) by halides, and the one-pot synthesis of alkylated PAN with benzyl chloride in the presence of sodium cyanide. The modified silica showed good catalytic activity for these reactions when dissolved in strong alkali solution. From the investigation of the catalysis and the scope of the reactions, a new concept, 'interfacial acceleration' instead of 'phase transfer', is introduced for the alkylation of PAN and the one-pot alkylation and synthesis of PAN in the presence of sodium cyanide utilizing the modified silica in the two-phase organic-aqueous system. Introduction The use of - polymers as support for catalysts or reagents is increasingly recognized [ 1 ]. Recently, the amino group immobilized on silica or alumina has been used in organic synthesis [2]. Such a system was used for alkylation of the activated methylene compounds in the 'bi- or tri-phase' system [3]. Kurusu has already tried to develop the silica-supported tri-phase catalysts for alkylation of phenylacetonitrile (PAN) and ran up against the difficulty that the modified silica catalyst was soluble in aq. alkali solution [4]. It is well known that the reaction of PAN with an alkyl halide needs a concentrated aqueous alkali solution such as 50% or 70% NaOH or KOH solution as the reaction medium [5 ]. Therefore, the authors chose to increase the hydrophobic character of the coupled silica to give resistance to the alkali by the secondcycle reaction with another silane coupling reagent (SCR). To investigate the reactivity of this modified silica, we chose the cyanide displacement reaction, the Knoevenagel reaction, the alkylation of PAN with benzyl chloride, and the one-pot alkylation in the reaction of benzyl chloride *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$5.00 0 1992 - Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved 216 with cyanide ion. This paper discusses the catalytic activity and behavior of silica catalysts containing the amino group. Experimental Materials Silica (MKC-500, specific surface area 497 m2 g-') was obtained from Nikki Chemical, activated by treatment with 6 N HCl, and dried in vacuum at 120 C. N-(2-aminoethyl)-3-aninopropyltrimethoxysilane (SH-6020) (I), 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (SS-1040) (II), and 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (SH-6040) (III) were obtained from Toray Silicone and used as obtained for a silane coupling reaction. Epichlorohydrin, a,a'-dichloro p-xylene, a,a'-dibromo-o-xylene, 1,6-dibromohexane, triethylenetetramine, 1,6-hexadiol diglycidyl ether, 1,4-buta.nediol diglycidyl ether, and benzaldehyde were purchased from Tokyo Kasei and used as received. Benzaldehyde and a-phenylethyl bromide were distilled for purification before use. Sodium cyanide, malononitrile, and dioxane were obtained from Wako Pure Chemical and used without further purification. Toluene was purified by distillation and dried by anhydrous sodium sulfate. Measurements Analysis and identification of the product distribution were carried out by gas chromatography using a Shimadzu GC-8A (PEG-20M 2 m x 2.6 mm) equipped with a CR-6A Chromatopac. Products were also analyzed by 'H NMR spectroscopy using a JEOL GY-270 and by FT-IR using a JEOL JORRFX 301 spectrometer. After cooling, the reacted silica gel was filtered and washed with benzene and diethyl ether, followed by purification with benzene in a soxhlet extractor for 12 h. The purified silica was washed again three times with diethyl ether and allowed to stand overnight in air. The yield of 1 was 8.7 g. The nitrogen content was 2.3896, which corresponded to 0.85 mmol g-1 of the grafted silane. 3 Aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (II) and 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (III) were also coupled onto silica gel in order to obtain grafted silica (2 and 3) by the same method mentioned above. The coupled silanes (II and III) contained 0.65 mmol g-' 2 and 0.31 mmol g-1 3, respectively. Cyanide displacement of a-Phenylethyl bromide To a solution of 0.49 g (10 mmol) of sodium cyanide and 2 ml distilled water, 0.15 g of la was added, followed by the introduction of 0.43 g (2 mmol) of a-phenylethyl bromide and toluene (1.0 ml). Then the solution was placed in an oil bath maintained at 45 C and stirred for 24 h. Or cooling, the modified silica used as catalyst was filtered off and washed with toluene, and the organic layer collected from the filtrate was concentrated by evaporation. The product was analyzed by GC. The yield of a-phenylethyl cyanide was 929u. 218 Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with maitrile To a solution of 0.1 g (1.5 mmol) of malononitrile dissolved in toluene (1.0 ml), 0.1 g of 1a was added, followed by 0.16 g (0.15 mmol) of benzaldehyde. The solution was placed in an oil bath maintained at 40 C with stirring for 23 h. After cooling, the catalyst was filtered off and washed with methanol. The filtrate was solidified and recrystallized in diethyl ether: yield 88%, m.p. 82-83.5 C (85 C [3]). Percentages found: C, 77.81; H, 3.84; N, 18.19'0. Calculated values for C1oH6N2: C, 77.90; H, 3.93; N, 18.1%. Alkytation of PAN with benzyl chloride by modified silica catalysts The general procedure is as follows: To a flask containing 5.0 ml of 50% NaOH, 0.3 g of the modified silica la was added, followed by the mixture of benzyl chloride (0.78 g, 6 mmol) and PAN (0.33 g, 2.9 mmol) in toluene (1 ml). Then the flask was placed in an oil bath maintained at 50 C with stirring for 7 h. After that, 10 ml of toluene was added to the reaction mixture (or, analysis of the organic phase by GC was carried out to determine the yield of products). The organic layer was transferred and filtered to remove any trace insoluble impurities, and the filtrate was evaporated until dry, and further purified by recrystallization in acetone. 0.84 g (9895) of a,a-dibenzylphenylacetonitrile was obtained; m.p. 89-90 C (m.p. 80-82 C [6], 92-92.5 C [7], 93-94 C [8]). Percentages found: C, 88.5490; H, 6.4690; N, 4.76/0. Calculated values for Cz2H19N: C, 88.84%; H, 6.4590; N, 4.7190. ALkylation of PAN with a-phenylethyl bromide and recycling of the catalyst To a flask containing 2.5 ml of 509'o NaOH, 0.15 g of modified silica 2a was added, followed by the addition of the mixture of PAN (0.19 g, 1.5 mmol) and a-phenylethyl bromide (0.59 g, 3 mmol) in toluene (0.5 ml). Then the flask was placed in an oil bath maintained at 70 C with stirring for 10 h. Then 10 ml of toluene was added to the reaction mixture. The organic layer was filtered to remove any trace insoluble impurities, and the solvent was evaporated to solidify the organic layer. Then the flask was placed in an oil bath maintained at 40 C with stirring for 48 h. After that, 10 ml of toluene was added to the reaction mixture. The organic layer was thoroughly transferred and filtered to remove any trace insoluble impurities. The filtrate was evaporated until the liquid product was obtained. The yield of a,a-dibenzylphenylacetonitrile was 68%. Results and discussion Cyanide displacement reaction The results of the cyanide displacement reaction with aq. solution of sodium cyanide are summarized in Table 1. The modified silica treated with epichlorohydrin or alkyl halides showed high activity because of the hydrophobic group. The displacement reaction proceeds easily on the solid surface of the modified silica, and a-phenylethyl cyanide was obtained from aphenylethyl bromide by nucleophilic attack of the cyanide ion. In experiments described in an earlier paper [4], hydrolysis of the halogen compound was observed because of the low amount of hydrophobic groups. However, when the amount of hydrophobic groups in the modified silica became high, the substitution of cyanide ion proceeded quantitatively. The higher the amount of hydrophobic groups contained in the modified silica, the more active the substitution. This observation implies that a highly concentrated region of the organic substrate appears around the more hydrophobic modified silica, and the displacement reaction proceeds easily on the surface of the modified silica. From these observations, the catalysts were effective for the reaction after they were dissolved in alkali solution in our system. Therefore, the catalysts, at least, had the structure depicted in Scheme 2; such a structure is analogous to that of a surface active reagent, and it is easy to understand that it behaves like a surface active reagent. Conclusions In our use of the modified silica, a kind of suspension or emulsion effect appeared in the reaction system when the stirring was continued for a long time. This suspension or emulsion effect may be considered a motive force for reaction (1). However, silica gel (Si02) was not better than the modified silica catalysts as the catalyst of this reaction, although the emulsion effect appeared in reaction (1) with silica gel POD. The catalysts with the compositions shown in Scheme 1 were effective for these reactions. In other words, to prepare an effective silica catalyst it is necessary to graft the compound containing the amino group onto silica, in order to immobilize the hydrophobic group on the modified silica. The reaction proceeds on the modified silica, when the phase is composed of liquids or solid and liquid. Consequently, we would like to introduce a new concept, `interfacial accelerator' instead of `phase transfer', for our system. The concept `interfacial accelerator' means that the catalysts will promote a special interfacial cooperation with reactants rather than carry a reactant from one phase to another phase. The catalysts dissolved in alkali solution could be reused without isolation from the mixture after separating the organic layer. This is also a convenient method since there is no need for regeneration and/or activation in the case of the second and third cycles. These activated silica catalysts were effective 224 for the following reactions: cyanide displacement with halide, the Knoevenagel condensation, and alkylation of PAN. Thus we were able to design and prepare a novel silica catalyst by functionalization of silica with SCR containing an amino group, followed by modification with epichlorohydrin and bis-halide compounds.
